name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

name: Graceanna
comment info: After studying the graph, the first thing that jumped out to me was the direction of the map, as it moves from inland to the sea, starting at 1 and ending at 5; a hurricane comes from the ocean to the mainland and follows the opposite path depicted in the graph. Therefore, the map cannot be a path of the movement of the hurricane. In addition, the fact that point 1, "different organizations make their forecasts", was outside of a circle and not even in the "cone" where the other circles are led me to the conclusion that this is probably because the different organizations (that may not be weather-related) may not have made valid hurricane predictions. After tracing the other circles, it appears that the smaller circles are more accurate, or they have more certainty regarding the hurricane.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

"Floridians beware; hurricane set to pass through entire state"

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graph shows a *sample* of the National Hurricane Center’s 5-day forecast of the center of a hurricane.  This is NOT the hurricane forecast cone for Dorian.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, September 12 with moderation on Wednesday, September 18.  The topic – tennis Grand Slams champions.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

The main cone of the storm is the NHC's prediction of where the storm will travel, but different organizations have also been tracing the storm, signified by the dotted lines. It is hard to accurately predict the weather, but it is easier to find a general area based on different spots.

name: Grace R
comment info: This graph shows the forecast for a hurricane that will affect Florida and regions surrounding it. I notice that the weather predictions are most precise during the earliest points after the hurricane makes landfall. This graph shows the most likely route for the hurricane, but it could take other paths. The farther away the hurricane is, the larger the circles become, showing that the weather predictions become less precise. Outside of the cone made by the circles, there is a shaded red area that could sill be affected by the storm. I wonder what hurricane this could be, or what the actual outcome was. I also wonder how the N.H.C. created this prediction. One possible title for this graph could be "Predictions for XYZ Hurricane".

replies.comment info:
HI, @Grace R --
You are a perceptive observer of the hurricane forecast cone.  

The National Hurricane Center (NHC) updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  This map is just an example, or as you have in your headline “XYZ”, and not for Dorian.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info: @Abby AOSE We wondered that same thing, about how the N.H.C. makes predictions and gathers data to make the predictions accurate.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

name: Moderator Tonya

And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

comment info: After studying the graph, the first thing that jumped out to me was the direction of the map, as it moves from inland to the sea, starting at 1 and ending at 5; a hurricane comes from the ocean to the mainland and follows the opposite path depicted in the graph. Therefore, the map cannot be a path of the movement of the hurricane. In addition, the fact that point 1, "different organizations make their forecasts", was outside of a circle and not even in the "cone" where the other circles are led me to the conclusion that this is probably because the different organizations (that may not be weather-related) may not have made valid hurricane predictions. After tracing the other circles, it appears that the smaller circles are more accurate, or they have more certainty regarding the hurricane.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

And, to follow the news on Dorian’s hurricane forecast cone and how it was interpreted, go to the breaking New York Times story athttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/11/us/politics/trump-alabama-noaa.html.

You can continue to post responses.  Please check back tomorrow --  Thursday afternoon, September 12 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and four Stat Nuggets.
 
The next graph will be released tomorrow -- THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, with moderation on WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 18.  You may respond before, during, or after the live moderation by going to ““What's Going On In This Graph?” Also, you can view the webinar with teachers and students discussing how to learn from graphs using The New York Times.  Go tohttps://webinars.on24.com/nyt/Graphs?partnerref=OnDemand.

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, who last lived through a hurricane in 1958, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, North Carolina, who has lived through five hurricanes, to date. (2 of 2)

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  Love the catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the map:  “Hulking Hurricane” by Ms. Hogan’s Period 7 class at Brooklyn Tech HS, “Predictions for Hurricane XYZ” by Grace R. of the Academy of Saint Elizabeth, and “Ripping and Roaring, Hurricane Soaring” by Sydney of Comet's class at Hanover-Horton HS.

Just a few notes for all. 

The hurricane forecast cone is a sample cone and not the cone for Dorian.   The article that included the map was published as Dorian was approaching the Bahamas.  (We will give you access to the article in tomorrow afternoon’s Reveal.) 

To learn more about the cone, go to this National Hurricane Center video (https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php) with two of their meteorologists explaining many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  They should be given an award for explaining this otherwise deceptively simple graph. 

To learn more about the probability model that is used to construct the cone, go to www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  (1 of 2)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Tiffany Emborgo

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Raquel Pasillas --

You are in luck.  There are two National Hurricane Center meteorologists who have a video that explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.  Here’s the URL:https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Raquel Pasillas

Welcome back to this year's "What's Going On In This Graph?" Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

To learn much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

"Floridians beware; hurricane set to pass through entire state"

replies.name: R
replies.comment info: @Luke Harris I like how you incorporated the use of technology in your answer!

Hi, @Luke Harris --

I, too, wonder how well the National Hurricane Center predicts a hurricane’s path.  It uses projects from the prior five years to inform their projections, but how often does a hurricane take a different turn?  If frequently, this would result in a larger area and, consequently, a larger radius for the circles.  For the 2019-2020 hurricane year, the radii are 41 miles for the one-day forecast and as much as 198 miles for the five-day forecast.  You can get more information on the hurricane cone at www.hnc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Also, search the NHC website for an explanation of how they determine the hurricane’s direction.

Good morning, @Abby AOSE --

Academy of St. Elizabeth -- welcome back to this year’s “What’s Going On In This Graph?”  Thank you for responding about what you notice and wonder about the graph, topped off with a headline.

Here are just a few comments about your terrific response.  

You write about the “misgiving” of the circles and the “unpredictable” hurricane.  The National Hurricane Center (NHC) describes the circles and circles by using the words “probable” and “likely.”  The hurricane forecast cone show the 60 – 70 percent probability that the center of the hurricane will be in the cone based on the past five years of forecasts.  

To learn more about the cone and how it is created go to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov.  (That’s plural for hurricanes, which is not surprising.)

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Lauren AOSE --

Let me just comment on the how the circles are determined.  
The size of the circles on the hurricane forecast cone are based on the forecasts from the past 5 years.  The radii are set for the coming year (2019-2020) with at 82 miles for a 24-hour (1 day) forecast and, at the furthest out forecast, 396 miles for 120-hour (5 day) forecast.  Read more about how these radii are set at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  Thank you for your thoughtful response.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ms. Hogan's Period 7 --

You respond, “We noticed that even though the storm's power will decrease over time, the NHC's prediction is uncertain enough that potential path of the storm is very large.”  I grant you that the graph does not say specifically that the hurricane cone is of the path of the *center * and not the entire sweep of the hurricane.  This is a major misunderstanding.  

Based on the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) forecasts over the past five years, the cone is drawn to contain the path of the center 60 to 70 percent of the time.  To learn more about how the cone’s location and size is calculated, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  

So, why does the cone increase in size with each successive day forecast?  Please share your reply.

HI, @Anakin L --

Tomorrow, we will give you the URL for the online article, which you can view for free.  It is interactive so more fun that this static image from the print version of the New York Times.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@brady morris

Welcome to "What's Going On in This Graph?"

This hurricane forecast cone is only an example created by the New York Times journalists and was released before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  This is a deceptively simple map. You may want to view the National Hurricane Center (NHC) video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.phpthat explains many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cone says and does not say.

You can tell the forecasted speed of the hurricane from the map.  How would the consecutive day hurricane centers be dispersed if the hurricane were moving quickly?  Slowly?  You can see what happened with Dorian here:https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/09/06/us/hurricane-dorian-path-map-track.html.

The NHC updates their hurricane forecast cone every 6 hours.  For Dorian, regretfully, I did not save all of the maps so we can’t look at the projections and analyze how accurate the forecasts were.  But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
@Zach Comet

Welcome to "What's Going On In This Graph?"

We tipped you off about the source of this hurricane forecast cone, which was published just before Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas.  The New York Times journalists wanted to show you that not all meteorologists agree.  Take a look at note #1 to find out about the dashed lines.

You can learn a lot more about the hurricane forecast cone from the National Hurricane Center’s video athttps://www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php.  There, meteorologists explain many of the misunderstandings about what the hurricane forecast cones show and what they do not show.

 To learn more about why the circles get larger the further out in the forecast and much more about the hurricane forecast cone, take a look at the NHC video at www.nhc.noaa.gov/cone_usage.php and read their explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.

But going to the NHC website at hurricanes.gov, you can do this for a future hurricanes.  (I checked.  Right now, there are no hurricanes in the Atlantic, Eastern North Pacific, or Central Pacific – the 3 regions that the NHC publishes forecast maps.)

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Joe Comet --
Thank you for jumping into the discussion of this graph just as it was released.

We tipped you off in the release that this was not Hurricane Dorian, but an example.  It was published before Dorian had gotten to the Bahamas.  

Take another read of what larger circles mean (note #4).  To learn more about how the circles are determined, read the National Hurricane Center’s explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  You may be surprised about the size of these circles and the probability that the center of the hurricane is within them.  

There is also a video that explains the hurricane forecast cone – what it tells you and what it does not.

HI, @Ms. Britt's Period 1 stats class --

Thank you for jumping on “What’s Going On In This Graph?” just when the graph was released on Thursday before the Wednesday’s moderation.  
Here are some suggestions on how to get your wonderings answered.  
Why do the circles overlap?  Well, look at how they are made.  To learn about how the radii are determined, you could read the National Hurricane Center’s (NHC) explanation at www.nhc.noaa.gov/aboutcone.shtml.  It has to do with 5 years of data and probability.  They use this data to also predict the speed of the hurricane.  There are other graphics the NHC releases that show the arrival time of winds and the warnings.  Any evacuation plans would be based on current data, past data, and local circumstances.
What you can see at the NHC is a use of statistics that can save lives!  
Are you now intrigued to study to be come a meteorologist?
